title: In Georgia, a Divided View on Reopening Businesses
summary: Some owners in Atlanta bristle, while others outside the area support efforts to restart the economy. ATLANTA-Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp's order allowing some nonessential businesses to reopen as soon as Friday is being met with skepticism by many residents and business owners here, while some outside the metro area welcomed the effort to restart the stalled economy.

title: Delta Reports First Loss in Five Years
summary: Airline is among first to detail coronavirus pandemic's impact on quarterly earnings. Delta Air Lines Inc. reported its first quarterly loss in over five years, as the coronavirus pandemic ravaged the travel industry.

title: Coronavirus Poses Hurdle for Goodwill Impairment Tests
summary: Finance executives are devoting more time and resources to determining whether they need to perform an impairment test and, if necessary, record a charge for goodwill. The unknown depth and duration of the coronavirus pandemic has disrupted finance chiefs' ability to generate sound forecasts, complicating efforts to conduct the required impairment tests for goodwill, securities lawyers and valuation experts say.

title: Victoria's Secret Buyer Seeks to Cancel Takeover After Coronavirus
summary: Private-equity firm wants to terminate $525 million investment citing store closures, furloughs. Private-equity firm Sycamore Partners wants to scrap its plans to take control of Victoria's Secret, a high-profile legal test of whether the coronavirus pandemic allows a buyer to walk away from an agreement reached before the outbreak.

title: Coronavirus Deaths in U.S. Nursing, Long-Term Care Facilities Top 10,000
summary: Industry says more testing is needed to detect and curb outbreaks, and some states boost efforts.

title: Bail Out the States?
summary: Any more federal aid should come with very strict conditions.. Congress is passing its fourth coronavirus relief bill this week, and already Democrats are teeing up the fifth. The main goal this time will be to bail out state governments, especially those run by Democrats and their allies in public unions. The question to ask is why taxpayers in Appleton and Sarasota should rescue politicians and unions in Albany and Springfield?

title: Paying Americans Not to Work
summary: Four GOP Senators were right about the harm from rich UI benefits.. Much of the harm from the coronavirus is unavoidable, but it would be nice if politicians didn't compound the damage by ignoring the laws of economics. The worst blunder so far on that score is the $600 increase in federal jobless benefits that is already undermining the economic recovery.

title: Mike Bloomberg, the $1 Billion Man
summary: He spent a fortune, but all he got was this lousy campaign T-shirt.. So much for the progressive meme about "buying elections." Federal disclosures Monday finally revealed the full bill for Mike Bloomberg's Democratic primary bid: more than $1 billion, for hardly three months of official campaigning. For comparison, that's more than either Donald Trump or Hillary Clinton spent during the whole of the 2016 race.

title: Progressive Genius Dept.
summary: New York's City Council wants to make a pandemic worse.. New York City has been hit especially hard by the coronavirus, and the City Council seems determined to hit it even harder. Crain's New York Business reports that the clever progressives who run the city government are proposing to slam businesses with new burdens even as hundreds of companies struggle to stay alive.

title: Hospitals Aim to Resume Procedures Postponed by Coronavirus
summary: Decisions pit vital revenue stream against infection risk; patchwork of state rules means uneven revival. Hospitals, clinics and surgery centers are moving tentatively to resume surgeries and other procedures that were halted when the coronavirus pandemic reached the U.S., a shift that could help stanch the sector's financial losses but presents new risks to infection control and public health.

title: Las Vegas Sands Posts Loss Amid Coronavirus Shutdown
summary: Casino operator's revenue falls 51% as pandemic upends operations on the Strip and in Macau. Casino operator Las Vegas Sands Corp. reported a 51% drop in revenue, with Las Vegas shut down in response to the coronavirus pandemic and reopened casinos in Macau struggling to recover.

title: 2016 Conventions Might Have Been the Last
summary: Will Democrats make it to Milwaukee and Republicans to Charlotte N.C.?. This summer the coronavirus may claim another victim: the Republican and Democratic national conventions, at least in their present form. While far less tragic than losing a human life, it would still be a significant and symbolic loss.

title: A Coronavirus Vaccine: Faster, Please
summary: Developing an inoculation is a slow and uncertain process. There are ways to make it more efficient.. Covid-19 cases, hospitalizations and deaths are leveling off in hot spots like Seattle and New York. New infections should soon begin to decline, and many parts of the country will be able to start a phased return to "normal." Yet without a vaccine, normality will look very different than it did before the pandemic.

title: Lockdown Is a Stress Test for Relationships
summary: The adversity of the pandemic and isolation is an emotional magnifier.. The Covid lockdown has been a harsh experience for one of my patients, a young professional woman. Isolated with her family in their second home, outside New York City, she has gotten in touch with her resentment of and dissatisfaction toward her husband.

title: PG&E CEO to Step Down After Tumultuous Year
summary: Bill Johnson took the helm at the San Francisco utility after it filed for bankruptcy due to its role in sparking deadly California wildfires. PG&E Corp.'s chief executive will step down following a tumultuous year overseeing the utility's attempts to improve safety and emerge from bankruptcy after its power lines sparked California wildfires that destroyed thousands of homes and killed more than 100 people.

title: A Soviet Refugee Visits the Supermarket
summary: As a child, I learned to take abundance for granted. Maybe now we'll all learn not to.. Lately I've been obsessed with my first memory of a supermarket. I couldn't believe the sheer amount of bright packaging sparkling from every shelf. I turned to my mom, whose face also looked blank with incomprehension. Walking through the aisles, I was scared to touch anything. I wanted to touch everything.

title: 'Shakespeare in a Divided America' Review: Protesting Too Much
summary: Throughout our nation's history, people on both sides of contentious political questions have appealed to the Bard for legitimacy.. In the late 1980s and early '90s, as America's "culture wars" began in earnest, "Shakespeare was dragged into the quarrel as rival camps fought over his place in the college curriculum. Those at one extreme argued that as a dead white male and agent of imperialism, Shakespeare should no longer be taught; those at the other celebrated him as a pillar of a superior Western civilization and complained that traditional approaches to teaching his plays had been supplanted by a focus on race and gender." So writes James Shapiro, a professor of English at Columbia University, in the conclusion of "Shakespeare in a Divided America: What His Plays Tell Us About Our Past and Future."

title: How We'll Live With Coronavirus
summary: Millions of years of learned human behavior, not Trump's tweets, are about to overwhelm the state lockdowns.. The coronavirus lockdown model is about to collapse beneath its own weight, undermined by politics, confusion about the virus itself, and the basics of human nature.

title: Monomoy Capital Hit With SEC Penalty Over Costs Imposed on Investors
summary: The New York private-equity firm will pay about $1.9 million to settle with the regulator. Private-equity firm Monomoy Capital Partners made its investors pay for the services of some firm employees without disclosing it, the Securities and Exchange Commission said.

title: Dallas Hotel Owner Is Biggest Beneficiary of Coronavirus Loan Program
summary: Lodging companies affiliated with hotelier Monty Bennett poised to receive $59 million in loans from U.S. Paycheck Protection Program. Monty Bennett's lodging business has been hit hard by the pandemic. He said Ashford Inc. and its subsidiaries have laid off or furloughed 95% of their 7,000 employees. An affiliated company, the owner of 117 hotels, stopped making payments on most of its $4 billion in debt, he said.

title: Public Companies Got $500 Million in Small Business Loans
summary: From S&W Seed to Potbelly, more than 100 public companies are among those receiving federal payroll aid. It wasn't just Ruth's Chris or Shake Shack that got coronavirus aid from the U.S. government. Dozens of publicly traded companies received forgivable loans totaling more than $500 million from the Small Business Administration's Paycheck Protection Program, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis.

title: New York City Council Wants to Open Some Streets to Pedestrians for Social Distancing
summary: Members focus on coronavirus response in body's first-ever teleconference meeting. The New York City Council introduced a slate of bills Wednesday focused on the city's coronavirus response, from extending a 90-day moratorium on evictions to mandating the city open miles of streets to pedestrians and cyclists.

title: Argentina Doesn't Make Foreign Debt Payments in Restructuring Standoff
summary: Move starts countdown to possible default unless authorities, bondholders reach an accord. Argentina said it didn't make foreign debt payments coming due on Wednesday-starting a countdown to a possible default next month unless authorities and bondholders can restructure tens of billions of dollars in sovereign debt.

title: U.S. Inflation-Protected Bonds Rally After Oil Prices Crash
summary: Move in TIPS yields signals investors expect future deflation as coronavirus pandemic creates economic havoc. Demand is surging for U.S. government bonds with returns adjusted for the rate of inflation as investors brace for a sharp economic downturn.

title: MLB Says Red Sox Broke Rules, but Blames Video Staffer
summary: Commissioner Rob Manfred said the team occasionally used video improperly, but his findings and penalties fell short of an earlier case against the Houston Astros. Major League Baseball's long-awaited investigation into allegations that the Boston Red Sox illegally stole signs on their way to a World Series championship in 2018 reached a clear conclusion: Yes, the Red Sox broke the rules. But don't even think about comparing them to the 2017 Houston Astros, baseball's most infamous cheaters in a century.

title: Small Hospitals Stumble Over Rules for Coronavirus Loans
summary: Bankruptcy protection and strategic alliances that keep small hospitals afloat disqualify them from aid. title: Trump Administration Unveils Plan to Distribute Aid to Hospitals
summary: Health and Human Services Department moves to end delay in allocating $70 billion from the previous stimulus. The Trump administration on Wednesday laid out plans to disburse $70 billion remaining from a congressional coronavirus relief plan for the nation's health system, following bipartisan criticism over delays in releasing the funds.

title: 'We Pulled the Plug': As Oil Prices Plunge, Drillers in the Gulf of Mexico Shut Off Wells
summary: The offshore sector accounts for roughly 15% of U.S. oil output, and as smaller drillers shut wells due to low prices, they worry some production may not return for years.. Offshore oil drillers have begun shutting off wells in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico following a collapse in crude prices due to the coronavirus pandemic, and some executives worry that the region's production may take years to fully recover.

title: For Insurers, Coronavirus Is a Curious Catastrophe
summary: So far, firms including Chubb and Travelers have taken relatively small direct hits from Covid-19. That could grow, but by how much is hard to say.. Major business insurers are calling potential losses from Covid-19 a catastrophe, like a hurricane or earthquake. But it is also something much more amorphous.

title: Mortality Rates Tell True Tale of Coronavirus's Effect
summary: Governments are studying overall death totals to determine when they can ease their lockdown measures. Governments considering reopening economies frozen by restrictions to limit the spread of the new coronavirus are struggling to determine how deadly it is. With tests for the virus still in short supply, many analysts are looking to the blunter measure of total deaths.

title: New York Preps for Large-Scale Testing Program to Combat Coronavirus Spread
summary: Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg will provide more than $10 million to design and help set up contact 'tracing army'. title: European Central Bank to Accept Some Junk-Rated Bonds as Loan Collateral
summary: ECB action aims to assist eurozone banks during coronavirus pandemic. FRANKFURT-The European Central Bank said it would accept some junk-rated bonds as collateral for its loans in its latest move to ensure eurozone banks can access central bank cash during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Amazon Deforestation Speeds Up as Coronavirus Hinders Enforcement
summary: Satellite data show steep increase in land clearing as health precautions thin ranks of forest's protectors. With hundreds of environmental enforcement agents sidelined by the pandemic, deforestation in Brazil's Amazon has increased to its fastest pace in years-and the season when clearing typically accelerates hasn't even begun yet.

title: New York MTA Approves Coronavirus Death Benefits Program
summary: Spouses or beneficiaries of employees who die from Covid-19 to receive $500,000, extended health coverage. title: U.S. Stocks Finish Higher, Clawing Back Some of Week's Losses

title: Oil Rebounds After Trump Signals Fresh Iran Tensions

title: Social Security Costs Expected to Exceed Total Income in 2021
summary: Trustees expect reserves to be depleted by 2035 as coronavirus weights on system's financial condition. WASHINGTON-The coronavirus pandemic is expected to weigh on the financial condition of Social Security, which is currently projected to pay benefits that exceed its income in 2021 for the first time in nearly 40 years.

title: Pakistani Authorities Seek Reinstatement of Death Penalty in Killing of Wall Street Journal Reporter

title: How Oil Markets Work, And Why Prices Fell Below Zero

title: Coronavirus Changes Trump Re-Election Calculus in Key States
summary: Rising job losses, coronavirus cases and political tensions may affect the president's prospects in the states that ensured his victory in 2016. title: Migrant Workers Set to Send Less Money Home, World Bank Says
summary: Historic drop expected in global remittances that many countries' economies increasingly depend upon. title: Tech Leaders Map Out Post-Pandemic Return to Workplace

title: Texas Instruments Bets Big on Shelf Life
summary: Chipmaker will keep running its fabs and build up inventory for recovery. For a conservative company, Texas Instruments Inc. is making a relatively bold gambit in the midst of the pandemic. It is one of the few chip companies that can afford to do so.

title: 'The Story of Plastic' Review: Putting the Earth in Our Hands

title: Trump's Best Re-Election Bet: Run Against Beijing

But it's increasingly clear that President Trump's likeliest path to re-election runs through Beijing. With the economy in shambles and the pandemic ravaging the country, making the election a referendum on China is perhaps Mr. Trump's only chance to extend his White House tenure past January 2021.

title: Oil Price Manipulation and Slippery Results
summary: While President Eisenhower may have acted decisively in 1957, his policies directly contributed to the so-called "oil crises" of the 1970s.. In "What Would Ike Do About Current Oil Price Collapse?" (Letters, Apr. 13), Prof. Arthur Cyr celebrates President Eisenhower's bringing "in line" the Texas Railroad Commission to "stabilize world oil markets" by increasing Texas oil output. Prof. Cyr fails to point out that Eisenhower next responded to the crisis with his 1959 Mandatory Oil Import Program that imposed quotas and licenses on foreign crude and that led directly to the oil crises of the 1970s. Herein are lessons for historians and policy makers today.

summary: The Cares Act has raised the Fed's fiscal actions to an entirely new level, further blurring the distinction between the Fed and the Treasury, as well as the distinction between monetary policy and fiscal policy..

title: NFL Teams Keep Dropping the Ball on Wide Receivers

The 2017 NFL draft was a curious one, and not only because the Chicago Bears spent months doing exhaustive research only to conclude they should take Mitchell Trubisky over Patrick Mahomes. For the first time in more than a decade, three wide receivers went in the top 10 picks. There were more wide receivers taken with the most valuable picks in the draft than any other position.

title: Small-Business Loan Fund May Run Dry Again. Is There Another Way?
summary: Lawmakers could put the payroll tax system into reverse to deliver money rather than collecting it. WASHINGTON-As Congress races to provide a fresh injection of aid to small businesses, lawmakers are contemplating a simpler, faster way to supply the next round of relief.

title: Hong Kong Charges Teens With Murder Tied to Protests
summary: Indictments are the most serious criminal charges so far linked to antigovernment unrest in the Chinese semiautonomous city last year. HONG KONG--Police charged two teenage boys with the murder of a 70-year-old man who was hit on the head by a brick thrown during one of the antigovernment street protests that rocked the city last year, the most serious criminal indictment to be brought over the unrest so far.

title: States Burn Through Cash for Unemployment Payments
summary: Nearly half of U.S. states have logged double-digit percentage declines in their trust-fund balances since the end of February. WASHINGTON-New York state has asked the federal government for a $4 billion no-interest loan to cover unemployment payments for people put out of work by the coronavirus pandemic as it and other states burn through funds set aside for jobless claims.

title: Trump Warns Iran Against U.S. Navy Harassment
summary: Officials said Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Navy made a series of dangerous moves near U.S. warships earlier this month. WASHINGTON-President Trump warned Iran Wednesday that he has instructed the U.S. Navy to "shoot down and destroy" Iranian gunboats if they continue to harass American ships in the Persian Gulf.

title: Gronk to the Beach! Tampa Bay Delivers a Predraft Surprise.
summary: A Patriots reunion captures headlines on the eve of the NFL's big night. I have no idea what the Tampa Bay Buccaneers are doing-I suspect the Buccaneers aren't totally sure, either-but I fully endorse the franchise's effort to entertain America amid these challenging, stay-at-home weeks.

title: Oil Market's Crisis Spreads to Individual Investors
summary: Many analysts caution that complicated products like the U.S. Oil ETF are too risky for retail investors. The collapse in crude prices is creating mounting losses for ordinary investors, a sign that the energy crisis is starting to ripple beyond the oil patch.

title: Coronavirus Forces New York to Send Bodies Out of State for Cremation
summary: Resume Subscription. New York City funeral directors, struggling with a surge of coronavirus deaths and tight regulations, are sending hundreds of bodies out of state for cremation.

title: The Joys-and Perils-of Working at Home Together
summary: With couples suddenly turning into co-workers, they are learning new things about themselves and their partners. Fawn and Keith Weaver spent months building a custom double-sided partners desk for their office, thinking it would be fun to sit across from each other on the occasional days they worked from home together. Then the quarantine hit.

title: Kim Kardashian West Wrote a Guide to Isolating With Kids. We Tried It
summary: The famous mom shared her guide to isolating with four children. In a subsequent backlash, she deleted it. But what if she was onto something?. As the parents of a six-year-old boy and a two-year-old girl, in this time of isolation, my husband and I haven't given up that much. Our social life was already on pause. There is always confusion, anxiety and fear-it's called bedtime. Like everyone else, we're just adjusting to doing conference calls while playing soccer, pretending to be a puppy while doing the laundry or trying to type with both a laptop computer and a laptop child. We are the lucky ones.

title: Rikers Island Guards Are Dying in One of the Worst Coronavirus Outbreaks
summary: The New York City correctional complex is among the most-infected workplaces in the U.S.. When Quinsey Simpson relieved a colleague at New York City's Rikers Island jail complex in early March, he had no idea his fellow correction officer was infected with the coronavirus.

title: Kimberly-Clark's Sales Top $5 Billion
summary: Consumers stocking up on products boosted all of its segments and main geographies. Sales at Kimberly-Clark Corp. , the seller of Scott and Cottonelle toilet paper and Kleenex, jumped to slightly more than $5 billion in the recent quarter as consumers stockpiled paper products.

title: The Unlikely Comeback of Elegant Opera Gloves
summary: Why the sophisticated style-seen on Miley Cyrus, Kylie Jenner and Helen Mirren-is more relevant than ever. EARLY IN HER MIDCENTURY tenure as Vogue's editor in chief, Diana Vreeland had Grace Mirabella, then a fashion editor and later her successor, restage an entire fashion editorial because of a seeming triviality: "You've ruined the texture of the coat by showing it with that jersey glove. Reshoot it with leather gloves," she commanded.

title: A Top Immunologist on Why Coronavirus Kills More African-Americans
summary: Head of Nashville's Meharry Medical College discusses Covid-19's outsize toll on people of color, why a vaccine might be far off. James Hildreth has been waging battle against viruses for four decades-first as a Rhodes scholar earning his Ph.D. in immunology, then as a researcher and physician working to bring better medical care to the fight against AIDS, particularly for African-Americans.

title: Students' Summer-Internship Plans Evaporate
summary: As companies continue work-from-home edicts, many students see their offers rescinded; 'It's demoralizing'. Last week, the online purveyor of home furnishings canceled its summer program.

summary: New applications have been suspended due to oversubscription; 4 million businesses have applied. WASHINGTON-The federal government has issued emergency grants totaling $3.29 billion to 755,476 small businesses across the country, along with loans worth $5.57 billion to nearly 27,000 businesses, according to data released this week.

title: Trump to Bar Immigration for Family of U.S. Citizens, Foreign Workers for 60 Days
summary: President says he plans to sign order Wednesday aimed at protecting American jobs; change wouldn't impact most employment-based immigration. WASHINGTON-President Trump said Tuesday that his administration would temporarily bar new immigrants, including some family members of U.S. citizens and foreign workers looking to move to the U.S., in the next 60 days under a new executive order.

title: Investors Cheer Snap's Shades of Grey
summary: Snap's first quarter results suggest a brighter picture for social media ad spending than many feared. Young users on "Coronacation" are flocking to social media, but advertisers aren't having much fun. Snap , Inc.'s latest results show they are, at least, still showing up.

title: Facebook Adds India's Richest Man as a Friend
summary: The social-media giant is paying $5.7 billion for better connections in its most promising growth market. Facebook may reign supreme in connecting people, but in the developing world it still needs help from local networks.

title: How Companies Are Finding Masks for Workers
summary: Retailers and restaurants that have stayed open in the pandemic are scouring the globe to find masks for employees to wear during shifts. Retailers and restaurants that have kept their doors open through the pandemic are buying up masks and gloves to protect their employees on the job. It hasn't been easy.

title: Globalized Commerce Might Prove Resilient to the Pandemic
summary: Companies might reshore some production of medical equipment for emergencies, but other international supply chains will be harder to break. The first examples of coronavirus-induced supply-chain shifts are under way. This week, Japanese consumer-products manufacturer Iris Ohyama announced it would take government subsidies to expand the production of masks domestically, adding to its existing production in China, the first company to do so.

title: Is Michael Jordan Really the Worst Dressed Athlete of all Time?
summary: With the new docuseries on the NBA all-star, 'The Last Dance,' airing on ESPN, there's a renewed focus on Michael Jordan's infamous fashion sense. But were his clothes actually so bad?. IT WAS THE BERET that got me. In the first episode of "The Last Dance," a new 10-part docuseries about Michael Jordan's 1997-1998 season with the Chicago Bulls, the team takes a preseason trip to Paris. There, Mr. Jordan did what so many deluded Americans have done before: He plopped on a beret. On the 6'6" athlete, however, the flat cap actually looked good. Wearing it quite comfortably, he peacocked convincingly during photoshoots and press conferences. As I watched the episode on ESPN last Sunday I could hardly believe my eyes: Might Mr. Jordan have been more stylish than I thought?

title: Oil Crash Comes Without Silver Lining
summary: This time around, sharp fall in oil prices is unmitigated negative for American economy. Low oil prices can wreak havoc with portions of the U.S. economy, but usually they come with an important offset: Consumers and businesses save a bundle on fuel. With most people not going much of anywhere during the coronavirus crisis, that offset isn't happening.

title: Singapore Built a Virus App, but It Hasn't Worked So Far
summary: The city-state's experience in digital contact-tracing holds lessons for other countries, including an Apple-Google effort in the U.S.. SINGAPORE-As governments around the world race to roll out contact-tracing phone apps to fight the coronavirus pandemic, an early experiment in Singapore faces a big hurdle: getting people to sign up.

title: Millions of Europeans Are on Paid Leave. Governments Are Picking Up the Tab.
summary: At least 18 million have been furloughed or laid off. Government programs to keep them on companies' payrolls are costing billions. At least 18 million European workers have been idled over the past month, according to government figures, as the new coronavirus pandemic cuts an ever-widening swath through the world's job markets and prompts governments to spend hundreds of billions of dollars to support furloughed and laid-off workers.

title: In Coronavirus Lockdown, People Are Finally Eager to Visit the Dentist
summary: Dr. Phil Cai's patients see an appointment as a chance to interact; suiting up for procedures is like 'going into war'. Dr. Phil Cai is experiencing something no dentist ever expects: Patients, starved for human connections, are actually happy to arrive at his office.

title: The Truck Industry Bets On the Other Electric Vehicle
summary: World's top two truck manufacturers are teaming up to develop hydrogen fuel cells. The truck industry is starting to take the other kind of electric vehicle more seriously.

title: For Roche, Demand for Coronavirus Products Offsets Disruption Elsewhere
summary: Swiss health-care giant reports strong demand for testing products and potential treatment. Demand for coronavirus testing and a potential treatment for patients with severe Covid-19 buoyed Roche Holding AG in the first quarter, even as the pandemic hit health-care provision in other disease areas.

title: Facebook Takes $5.7 Billion Stake in India's Jio Platforms
summary: Deal gives Facebook opportunity to bring WhatsApp service into closer partnership with one of India's biggest telecom providers. Facebook Inc. said it would pay $5.7 billion for just under 10% of Indian telecom operator Jio Platforms Ltd., a massive expansion of the social media giant's commitment to a promising market where it has faced difficulties.

title: Senate Passes Bill for More Small-Business Stimulus
summary: $484 billion bill now goes to the House, where a vote is expected Thursday. WASHINGTON-Congressional leaders struck a deal with the White House Tuesday to send hundreds of billion of dollars in fresh aid to small businesses and hospitals, the federal government's latest effort to keep pace with the twin economic and public health crises created by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Adversaries Are Accelerating, Coordinating Coronavirus Disinformation, Report Says
summary: An echo chamber fed by China, Russia and Iran feeds denigrating information about the U.S., according to State Department assessment. WASHINGTON-The State Department has assessed that Russia, China and Iran are mounting increasingly intense and coordinated disinformation campaigns against the U.S. relating to the outbreak of the new coronavirus, according to an internal report.

title: Some States Look to Reopen, but Others Want More Testing First
summary: Attorney General says Justice Department would consider backing those who claim states' coronavirus policies violate their rights. U.S. governors are pursuing different routes to restart local economies hit by the coronavirus pandemic, with several Southern leaders moving to reopen businesses while others voice concern about taking such steps without more robust testing capacity.

title: Hospitals Secure More Aid in Latest Coronavirus Bill
summary: Senate passes $75 billion in funding as part of emergency package. WASHINGTON-Hospitals and health providers stand to get $75 billion under the coronavirus package passed by the Senate on Tuesday, funds aimed to help offset the costs from a surge in coronavirus cases and lost revenue due to the delaying of elective procedures.

title: Delta CFO Calls Off Retirement as Pandemic Hits Airline's Finances
summary: The airline says its finance chief, Paul Jacobson, will stay with Delta for many years to come. Longtime Delta Air Lines Inc. finance chief Paul Jacobson has called off his retirement plans as the company navigates the fallout from the coronavirus pandemic, which has hammered the airline industry.
